item.title: Palabra del día en inglés: ‘didactic’
item.description: Esta palabra ha aparecido en 58 artículos en NYTimes.com en el último año. ¿Puedes usarla en una frase?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: ¿Fumar de vez en cuando es realmente malo?
item.description: Preguntamos a los expertos si fumar de vez en cuando es, esencialmente, jugar con fuego.
item.dc:creator: Kara McGrath

media:content.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: Word of the Day: didactic
item.description: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
item.dc:creator: The Learning Network

item.title: El incendio mortal de un bar que sacudió a un pueblo suizo
item.description: En la estación de esquí de Crans-Montana, donde el fuego dejó al menos 40 muertos en Año Nuevo, la comunidad trata de entender una tragedia sin precedentes.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic, Aurelien Breeden and Sergey Ponomarev

media:content.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Pitt,’ Plus 10 Things to Watch on TV This Week
item.description: The series, set in a Pittsburgh emergency room and starring Noah Wyle, returns. And a new group of players enter a castle in Scotland for “The Traitors.”
item.dc:creator: Shivani Gonzalez

media:content.media:credit: Warrick Page/Max
media:content.media:description: Noah Wyle in “The Pitt.”

item.title: 32 cubanos murieron en Venezuela, dicen las autoridades de Cuba
item.description: Según el presidente Miguel Díaz-Canel, las bajas eran parte de las fuerzas armadas o del Ministerio del Interior de su país. El país es un aliado histórico de Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Antenas alcanzadas por ataques aéreos estadounidenses en Caracas, Venezuela, el domingo.

item.title: After Christmas Day Strikes, Fear Grips Muslims in Rural Nigeria
item.description: A small town set amid a smattering of baobab trees is grappling with the aftermath of a bombing ordered by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Taibat Ajiboye for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Debris from a missile landed near a round well, center, in Jabo, Nigeria, and burned corn stalks that had been gathered for cattle feed.

item.title: Quote of the Day: Humbled Is the Hand That Holds Hickory
item.description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 5, 2026.

item.title: No Corrections: Jan. 5, 2026
item.description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 5, 2026.

item.title: Trump Suggests U.S. Could Take Action Against More Countries
item.description: On Air Force One, President Trump threatened Colombia and its president, described Cuba as “ready to fall” and reasserted his desire to acquire Greenland.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Asked on Air Force One on Sunday whether his administration would target Colombia, President Trump replied, “It sounds good to me.”

item.title: Cuba Says 32 of Its Citizens Died in Venezuela, Including Military Personnel
item.description: President Miguel Díaz-Canel said the casualties were from Cuba’s armed forces or interior ministry. The country is a longstanding ally of Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Antennas hit by U.S. airstrikes in Caracas, Venezuela, on Sunday.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Calls for Dialogue and ‘Coexistence’ With U.S.
item.description: Acting President Delcy Rodríguez struck a more diplomatic tone than she had on Saturday, inviting the United States to “work together on a cooperative agenda.”
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles

media:content.media:credit: Leonardo Fernandez Viloria/Reuters
media:content.media:description: Delcy Rodríguez, now Venezuela’s acting president, in Caracas last year.

item.title: Brain Health Challenge: Test Your Knowledge of Healthy Habits
item.description: It’s never too early or too late to start healthy brain habits. Today, test your knowledge with a pop quiz.
item.dc:creator: Dana G. Smith

item.title: Rubio enfatiza que el plan de EE. UU. es presionar a Venezuela en lugar de gobernarla
item.description: El secretario de Estado dijo que se mantendría la “cuarentena” militar sobre algunas exportaciones de petróleo para presionar a los dirigentes en funciones del país.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: El secretario de Estado Marco Rubio en una rueda de prensa con el presidente Trump en Mar-a-Lago, la finca privada y club del presidente en Palm Beach, Florida, el sábado por la mañana.

item.title: Delcy Rodríguez, Venezuela’s New Leader, Faces Big Test
item.description: Delcy Rodríguez is the torchbearer of a government whose revolutionary roots are in disarray. She must appease constituencies who loathe U.S. meddling while fielding Washington’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Isayen Herrera and María Victoria Fermín

media:content.media:credit: Gaby Oraa/Reuters
media:content.media:description: A photo of Venezuela’s new leader, Delcy Rodríguez, from August. With her were Foreign Minister Yvan Gil, left, and a Venezuelan lawyer, Larry Devoe.

item.title: 10-Minute Challenge: An Artist in Greenland
item.description: We’d like you to look at one piece of art for 10 minutes, uninterrupted.
item.dc:creator: Larry Buchanan

item.title: Trump’s Move for Regime Change in Venezuela Threatens a New MAGA Rift
item.description: Some Republicans are asking how Mr. Trump’s military intervention in Venezuela squares with his past pledges to avoid foreign entanglements and nation building.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Kellen Browning

media:content.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
media:content.media:description: President Trump and members of his administration have offered differing explanations of what would happen in Venezuela now that the United States has captured its leader, Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: Maduro’s Capture Shows Trump’s Goal to Dominate the Americas
item.description: Latin America was already struggling with how to handle President Trump’s interventions in the region. Then he attacked Venezuela.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.category: Community of Latin American and Caribbean States

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Jesus Linares, 48, and Reggie Carrero, 52, in a damaged apartment on Sunday in Catia La Mar, Venezuela, after strikes conducted by the U.S. military as part of the operation to capture Nicolás Maduro.

item.title: ‘Nos están invadiendo’: el ataque estadounidense visto desde los celulares en Venezuela
item.description: Las videos, grabados principalmente por personas en Caracas y La Guaira, captaron en tiempo real la incursión aérea y terrestre de EE. UU.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Arijeta Lajka and McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:credit: via Reuters

item.title: Robert Heide, Daring Playwright and Warhol Collaborator, Dies at 91
item.description: He helped create the Off Off Broadway theater scene, wrote and acted in Andy Warhol’s films, and turned his fascination with collectible Americana into books.
item.dc:creator: Alex Traub

media:content.media:credit: Billy Name Estate, via Dagon James
media:content.media:description: Mr. Heide in a photo from the 1960s.

item.title: Winter Storms Ease Drought in California, for Now
item.description: Experts say that it’s too early to tell what will happen during the rest of the state’s rainy season, but that extreme drought is unlikely.
item.dc:creator: Sonia A. Rao

media:content.media:credit: Stephen Lam/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
media:content.media:description: Streets were flooded along the swollen Corte Madera Creek during a king tide in Corte Madera, a town north of San Francisco, on Saturday.

item.title: NYT Crossword Answers for Jan. 5, 2026
item.description: Lynn Lempel helps our minds wander.
item.dc:creator: Sam Corbin

item.title: Critics Choice Awards 2026: The Complete Winners List
item.description: “One Battle After Another” won best picture, while the top acting honors went to Timothée Chalamet (“Marty Supreme”) and Jessie Buckley (“Hamnet”).
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

media:content.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Critics Choice
media:content.media:description: From left, Benicio del Toro, Leonardo DiCaprio, the casting director Cassandra Kulukundis, the director Paul Thomas Anderson and Chase Infiniti, accepting best picture for “One Battle After Another.”

item.title: Los casos de Maduro y Hernández revelan la geopolítica de Trump
item.description: Las imputaciones contra el presidente de Venezuela y el expresidente de Honduras se parecen, pero entre una captura y un indulto se abre una brecha política difícil de explicar.
item.dc:creator: Jonah E. Bromwich

media:content.media:credit: Jorge Cabrera/Getty Images
media:content.media:description: Cuando el presidente de Honduras, Juan Orlando Hernández, fue extraditado en 2022, la capital de su país lo celebró. De todos modos, el presidente Trump lo indultó el mes pasado.

item.title: Days After U.S. Strikes in Nigeria, Gunmen Kill Dozens of Villagers
item.description: The attackers also abducted an unspecified number of people, including students from a Catholic school where over 300 people were kidnapped in November.
item.dc:creator: Saikou Jammeh, Ismail Alfa and Eric Schmitt

media:content.media:credit: Ifeanyi Immanuel Bakwenye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
media:content.media:description: The road leading to St Mary’s Catholic School in Papiri, Niger State, in November 2025.

item.title: How Venezuelans Worldwide Reacted to Overthrow of Maduro
item.description: For Venezuelans living abroad, news of the U.S. military intervention and President Nicolás Maduro’s capture triggered a wide spectrum of emotions, ranging from joy to anger and uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
media:content.media:description: In Caracas, the streets were silent on Saturday, save for a few small demonstrations organized by the government to protest Nicolás Maduro’s ouster.

item.title: Imágenes satelitales muestran daños en la base donde fue capturado Maduro
item.description: Las imágenes del antes y del después publicadas el domingo muestran que al menos cinco edificios del complejo fueron destruidos por las fuerzas estadounidenses.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Lee el acta de imputación contra Nicolás Maduro, en inglés
item.description: El presidente venezolano fue acusado de narcoterrorismo y conspiración para importar cocaína en EE. UU., entre otros cargos. Su esposa, Cilia Flores, también fue acusada.

item.title: Maduro’s Ouster Plays Right Into Putin’s Hands
item.description: Allies? Who needs allies?
item.dc:creator: M. Gessen
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

media:content.media:credit: Photo illustration by The New York Times

item.title: Así fue la captura de Maduro, en fotos, mapas y videos
item.description: Lo que sabemos sobre la secuencia de los acontecimientos, desde los ataques aéreos iniciales en los alrededores de Caracas hasta la incursión al complejo de Maduro y su traslado a Nueva York.
item.dc:creator: Lazaro Gamio, Martín González Gómez, Malika Khurana, Elena Shao, Aric Toler and Agnes Chang

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Venezuela, Democracy and Oil
item.description: One thing is clear after the U.S. raid: Gunboat diplomacy is back, with cascading implications not just for the Americas but for the world.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times

item.title: Exiled Venezuelans Celebrate Maduro’s Downfall, but Are Wary
item.description: “I had utterly lost hope,” said one Venezuelan who has lived in exile from his country for seven years.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak

media:content.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Venezuelans took to the streets of Cúcuta, Colombia, to celebrate on Saturday.

item.title: Satellite Imagery Reveals Damage to Venezuelan Base Where Maduro Was Captured
item.description: Before-and-after imagery released on Sunday shows that at least five buildings at the complex were destroyed by U.S. forces.
item.dc:creator: Sanjana Varghese
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Francis Patrelle, Champion of the Story Ballet, Dies at 78
item.description: Founding his own company, he built a tightly knit community in New York around his classes. His “Nutcracker,” set in the city in 1895, was his most popular production.
item.dc:creator: Marina Harss

item.title: The Venezuela I Know
item.description: Many are celebrating the ouster of a brutal dictator, but the Maduro regime may survive the loss of Maduro.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kristof

media:content.media:credit: Maxwell Briceno/Reuters

item.title: Mamdani Names Dina Levy as NYC Housing Leader and Pledges ‘Rental Rip-off’ Hearings
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani named a housing commissioner and announced that the city would hold public hearings where frustrated renters could voice their complaints.
item.dc:creator: Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Christopher Maag
item.category: Department of Housing Preservation and Development (NYC)

media:content.media:credit: Ryan Murphy for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani appointed Dina Levy, a New York State housing official, to head New York City’s Department of Housing Preservation and Development.

item.title: Top Democrats Say Trump Has Still Not Briefed Congress on U.S. Military Action in Venezuela
item.description: By Sunday evening, Trump administration officials had agreed to provide a briefing on Monday, after pleas from Democrats to fill them in on action that President Trump had taken circumventing Congress.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the House minority leader, said Democrats would prioritize reining in President Trump “to ensure that no further military steps occur absent explicit congressional approval.”

item.title: Behind the Scenes of Our Nicolás Maduro Front Page
item.description: After President Trump’s surprise ouster of Venezuela’s authoritarian leader, a team of New York Times editors set to work redoing the front page.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: ‘They’re Invading Us’: The U.S. Attack Viewed From Venezuelans’ Cellphones
item.description: The videos, filmed on cellphones by people mainly in Caracas and La Guaira, showed the exact moments in which the U.S. air and ground incursion played out in real time.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Arijeta Lajka and McKinnon de Kuyper

media:content.media:credit: via Reuters

item.title: Así se decantó Trump por Delcy Rodríguez como dirigente de Venezuela
item.description: Semanas antes de la captura de Nicolás Maduro, funcionarios de EE. UU. ya tenían una candidata para sustituirlo: la vicepresidenta Delcy Rodríguez.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Tyler Pager, Simon Romero and Julie Turkewitz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

media:content.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Vice President Delcy Rodríguez of Venezuela, now the country’s interim leader, speaking at the United Nations General Assembly in New York in 2019.

item.title: Venezuela se muestra desafiante mientras los aliados de Maduro dicen que siguen a cargo
item.description: La Casa Blanca ha dicho que cree que el gobierno de Venezuela, bajo el liderazgo interino de Delcy Rodríguez, acabará cediendo. Se desconoce la naturaleza de las conversaciones privadas entre el gobierno venezolano y los funcionarios estadounidenses.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Venezuelans took to the streets of Cúcuta, Colombia, to celebrate on Saturday.

item.title: Ukrainians Welcome a U.S. Victory in Venezuela, and Lament a Double Standard
item.description: Ukraine’s government supports the removal of a dictator while members of Parliament question the wisdom of endorsing military interventions, even against a Russian ally.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer

media:content.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
media:content.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers salvaging parts from a Russian armored vehicle in Bucha, Ukraine in 2022. Some Ukrainians worry that the U.S. intervention in Venezuela and capture of its president will encourage Russia to toughen its military pressure on Ukraine.

item.title: Venezuelans Brace for Uncertainty After U.S. Military Operation
item.description: People in Venezuela stocked up on supplies after the U.S. military struck the country and seized its president, Nicolás Maduro, in a pre-dawn raid on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Paik and Axel Boada

media:content.media:credit: Ariana Cubillos/Associated Press

item.title: Ginger Chicken Soup With Zucchini and More Easy, Healthy Recipes
item.description: Our new collection of healthy dinner recipes is full of doable, delicious recipes to make on repeat, like this ginger chicken and rice soup with zucchini.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Ko

media:content.media:credit: Linda Xiao for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Yossy Arefi.
media:content.media:description: Yossy Arefi’s ginger chicken and rice soup with zucchini.

item.title: Venezuela’s New Leader Softens Tone as Trump Threatens Colombia
item.description: Acting President Delcy Rodríguez raised the prospect of dialogue after defiant remarks from Venezuelan officials. President Trump suggested the U.S. could take action against other countries, including Colombia.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

media:content.media:credit: The New York Times
